title: Wednesday, 14th March, 2018

BE11:09am

And now there's no Fleet Street, so .... well, rien n'est éternel, I guess.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Anyway, the other thing that happened between yesterday's session and now is that Conviviality Retail checked its doormat.

BE11:09am

Extraordinary statement from them this morning.

BE11:10am

Further to the announcements made by Conviviality Plc on 8 March 2018 and 13 March 2018, the Company yesterday identified a payment due to HM Revenue & Customs of approximately £30.0 million which falls due for payment on 29 March 2018 and which has not been accrued for within its short term cash flow projections. This has created a short term funding requirement. The Company's announcement on 13 March 2018 confirmed an expected range of adjusted EBITDA of between £55.3 million and £56.4 million. To the extent that the current situation creates operational difficulties, this may negatively impact the adjusted EBITDA range.

The Company is currently in compliance with its banking covenants. The next covenant test date is 29 April 2018. The Company is subject to two banking covenants (i) for covenant debt (which excludes any amount drawn down under the Company's invoice discounting facility) to be less than 2.5 times the last 12 months adjusted EBITDA, and (ii) adjusted EBITDA to be at least 4 times the net financial charge. The Company is fully drawn under its term loans and revolving credit facility and covenant net debt at 29 April 2018 is expected to be approximately £113.0 million (which excludes any amount drawn down under the Company's invoice discounting facility). Based on the expected adjusted EBITDA of between £55.3 million and £56.4 million, this would give rise to a covenant test result of 2.04x to 2.00x adjusted EBITDA. The Company continues to expect net debt to be approximately £150.0 million for the period ending 29 April 2018 including the invoice discounting facility.

The Company has engaged PwC to assist it in its forthcoming discussions with HM Revenue & Customs and its key stakeholders including its lending banks, credit insurers, suppliers and other creditors, as well as to determine the potential impact of any resulting funding requirement on the Company's adjusted EBITDA expectation and compliance with its banking covenants. Following preliminary advice received from PwC, whilst there can be no guarantee, the Board believes this short term funding requirement will be satisfactorily resolved.

i Congrats FT.. keep up the quality journalism

11:24 am
BE11:25am

A reported run rate on seven weeks data of c.15% (simple funerals / total funerals) is 5pc points better than management’s early expectation in Jan’18 of c.20%. We estimate that every 1pc point less cannibalization of the Traditional business puts c.3% on our estimated 2018 earnings. Combined with 7% growth in total number of deaths (first two months of 2018 v first two months of 2017) against our expectation of a modest decline, we can see how substantial upgrades to 2018 earnings consensus forecasts may be deliverable in due course. However, the statement contains limited detail on…

Grouchmonkey Can we do EMIS later pl?
Stateless DTY was down 65% yesterday, now only down 60%.
BE11:26am

…Cost initiatives, which we expect will be communicated in May’18 (trading update) with further details in Aug’18 (interim results).

 Outlook for 2018+: Management restates its aim to protect market share by focusing on (1) new services and (2) pricing. We believe that this will create a new platform for sustainable and material FCF generation (we expect greater than £47m of UFCF to be generated in FY’18). Executive Directors have decided to voluntarily waive their entitlement in full to 95% of the maximum amount possible of their annual bonus opportunity. No board member will receive an increase in basic salary or fees in 2018.

BE11:27am

But, yes, as the ROTR point out, you can make a valuation argument here.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Which Panmure does.

BE11:27am

Valuation: After halving in Jan’18 following the announcement of the price cut/freeze, the shares have bounced 17% from their Feb’18 low point to trade on a Dec’18 PE of c.13.3x, over 50% below our (unchanged) target price of 1410p (21x PE). We expect UFCF to grow post 2018 driven by (a) strong crem and pre-paid markets (b) growth in UK deaths (c) cost cutting to benefit margin (d) greater elasticity than expected in response to the Jan’18 price cut. Our SOTP analysis suggests the funeral business is trading at a c.30% discount to international funeral peers.

Jimmy what is Shrewdette saying today BE?

Punter Agree Stateless on DTY and its statement a bit more positive than expected. Would be more interested in any grey on how to value the two bits of Pru post demerger

BE11:29am

Peel Hunt.

Miss Piggy retail sales?
BE11:29am

Full-year results were slightly behind expectations with adj PBT +3%. This is all historic given the change in price policy in January (25% reduction in Simple Funeral). The proportion of Simple funerals has increased from 7% to 15% thus far vs guidance of 20% (if it remained at this level it would add £5m to numbers). However, the company will shortly trial changes to its traditional funeral pricing, which will impact profits. The company is also reviewing the cost base, which should start to benefit in Q4. Caution is required given the potential reaction of competitors and as Dignity’s full price offer is market-leading in both funerals and crems.

2:50 Coral Cup 6 & 7 places on offer 27 runners, so in this order - Mount Mews 11/1, Top of the Game 12/1, William Henry 8/1 and longshot Mischievous Max 33/1. !!
3:30. QM Champ Chase. It's got to be Altior even money fav. I've also done Politologue 14/1 to pick up place.
4:10 the cross country chase - always fascinating. Cause of Causes 3/1 serial Chelters winner, french raider Urgent De Gregaine 16/1 was second in Czech pardubicka, and The Last Samuri 5/1 trying new discipline after seconds at Aintree.
4:50. Very open juveniles - I'm going with couple of Northerners - Look My Way 9/1 EW and The King Of May 10/1 EW. 5 places on offer.
And in the 5:30 final 'bumper' Acey Milan 13/2 EW again 5 places on offer.

BE11:32am

Good luck all!

We can rattle though Pru quickly, as it's covered at length elsewhere.

11:32 am
Prudential PLC (PRU:LSE): Last: 1,926, up 100 (+5.48%), High: 1,943, Low: 1,897, Volume: 3.47m
BE11:33am

Splitting M&G off the Asia bit. Simple argument says you stick the Asia bit on the same rating as AIG and you get about 10% more than the current SOTP.

Bonnemort Now is the time to profit from funerals, as early Boomers and pre-Boomers with houses and pensions go. Be a bad business when Millennial renters on DC pensions are shuffling off.
BE11:34am

Though you'll have to wait until 2020, most likely.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Quick bit of SOTP work from Panmure.

BE11:34am

We have said previously that if the UK business was demerged we
think that the balance of the business could receive a rating more akin to that of Asian rival
AIA. Our previous Sum of the Parts (SOTP) valuation was based on the UK and US valued at
Embedded Value whilst Asia was at Embedded Value plus 5x new business profit. We now
believe that Asia should be trading on a higher new business multiple (Asian peer AIA is on
c12x) given the demerger and so have increased our Asian new business multiple from 5x
to 7x. The impact based on the just announced EV figures increases our target price from
2210p to 2552p/share.

BE11:35am

Did I say AIG? I meant AIA, of course.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Forester Down my way in gods waiting room, woodland burials are becoming very popular
BE11:36am

However, all this is a lot of faff for ~10% upside in two years.

Soundbuy @Forester - we call it fly-tipping down our way
BE11:37am

The better argument, maybe, is that Pru's breaking up because it has to.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

It's not a "releasing hidden value" thing, it's a regulatory necessity.

BE11:37am

Barclays incoming:

BE11:37am

We believe the demerger was inevitable, c 2/3 of Prudential’s capital is in the UK (due to Solvency 2), while only 1/3 of the value. On our last published sum of the parts valuation (at February 2018 of £22.86, c30% or 650p of the value in the UK and asset management (note, asset management includes EastSpring, which is c50p of this valuation). The Asia business alone, putting it on a AIA multiple, is worth £14.38p per share (63% of our sum of the parts and 80% of our price target). Prudential is our top pick among European insurers, with 20% upside to our £22.02 price target (sum of the parts of £22.86 is our upside valuation case), primarily because of its exposure to Asia, and today’s announcement in our option will help Prudential realize this value. Although as we have seen with Old Mutual (EW), these processes are not necessarily simple, particularly with question marks on the capital requirements each division will require and how the corporate debt is allocated, although for Pru, this demerger could help to free capital in the Asian operations and potentially remove concerns on Sol2 equivalence on its US operations. We reiterate our Overweight rating.

11:37 am
BE11:38am

And Citi.

BE11:38am

Pru trades at around a 10% discount based on peer multiples. There are plans to separately list the UK/ European insurance & asset management business and the Asian/ US ones. Both will be listed in separately in London. We currently value M&G Pru at £12.7bn equivalent to 13x earnings (and ~20% of the total group). As a partial break-up we expect some focus on the potential to unlock value on a sum-of-the parts basis. Relevant peer multiples suggest that Pru trades at ~10% discount, a figure that has been broadly stable recently. Given issues with peer comparability this is an unconvincing level. Instead we see the decision driven more by the future direction and investment needs of M&G Pru in a fluid market place, where separate management can give it the attention it needs. This is eminently sensible, even if not particularly value creative in the near term.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

The stock has marked down heavily on a series of unfortunate events even though most sell-side brokers have been Buyers. It is a sober reminder of how difficult it is for investors to ignore the ‘thousand cuts’ and focus on the payday ahead when ‘the market’ finally rerates the mispriced long duration cash flows. At Shire both execution and communication need to improve for this to happen. In our view there are levers the CEO and new CFO (who joins mid March) can pull to now do it.

SoS Apologies - of course Miss Piggy
BE11:44am

I'll skip the stuff about competitive dynamics in haemophilia, because I suspect the people taking a keen interest in Shire don't really care overly what the company actually does.

BE11:45am

Valuation: Shire is poorly valued on consensus estimates due to concerns that its haemophilia and HAE franchises are not sustainable and that it cannot service its debts without ADHD. We strongly disagree. Our TP of £75 is an average of 2018-20e EV/EBITA multiples (£64) and DCF (£86). Applying the 20x P/E Sanofi paid for Bioverativ would value Shire’s haemophilia business at £20/share. We continue to value ADHD at £10/share. Subtracting this £30 from the current share price implies that the remaining franchises (which account for nearly 50% of group EPS and are all durable, in our view) trade on a low-single-digit 2018e P/E – hardly rational.

11:45 am

BE11:55am

In summary, we think: (1) Unilever has already made a credible case for why NV and PLC should unify; (2) the reporting currency and the size, liquidity and valuation of NV vs PLC could make the Netherlands a practical choice; (3) however, Unilever will need to explain the motives of its HQ choice carefully in the context of Brexit and the protective measures the Dutch laws permit. We stress that we have no knowledge of what the outcome will be.

Our understanding is that if Unilever were to fund a US acquisition with equity under its current structure, the shareholders of the target might not get capital gains roll-over relief. We think a unified legal structure might solve this problem, and could make demergers easier as well. (Note – we are not legal experts.)

[T]here could be implications for listing and corporate governance. Dutch law embeds a
broad 'stakeholder' framework and permits Stichtings, which many investors view as protectionist measures against takeovers. In this context, we think Unilever's recent comments on the Trust Office (its Stichting structure) and on upholding good corporate governance should alleviate the market's concerns on protectionism.
